commentBody:
I asked about your favorite ending of CLUE, the classic murder mystery movie, so it's only fair to share mine. [Spoiler Alert!]

‚ÄúBut here‚Äôs how it really happened.‚Äù

The last (and best) ending reveals that each victim was killed by a different character, and each killer had a different motive.

The highlights are when Professor Plum (Christopher Lloyd) learns he killed the wrong man (‚ÄúOh shucks,‚Äù he replies.) and when Mrs. White (Madeline Kahn) stammers about her anger feeling like "flames on the side of my face!"

Best of all, this is the only ending where Tim Curry is revealed to be one of the bad guys, a role he plays so well.
What a fantastic debut! Such a fun solve and a superb theme and revealer. Well done!

Not sure why BALI is clued as a "getaway" when it is merely an island. And a NEONATAL NURSE would be too young to be a nurse. I know I have idiosyncratic taste, but why should SOLOS be clued as "Climbs without a partner" when the word means doing *anything* without a partner?

I was stuck trying to figure out what Yogi Berra was once. I would posit that Yogi Bear was created fully formed, and due to the magic of television, never at any moment was a BEAR CUB. 

Unless he was also a baseball player, and played at Wrigley Field.
Fun theme. I got 3/4 of the themers on the first pass, no crosses. While doing the puzzle, it seemed harder than a typical Tuesday, but still finished in Monday time so ü§∑üèæ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
That was so enjoyable I came right here to comment! The theme rocked my socks off.

I found this one of the easiest NYT puzzles in recent memory. Maybe it and yesterday's grid should have switched places? 

I still enjoyed the solve. The theme was quite nice, and the fill had its moments - I especially liked "Yogi, once" for BEAR CUB featuring right after "Yogi's pose."

I have one nit to pick though. The Inca weren't really pyramid builders, unlike the Maya or Aztec people, were they?
Cute theme!

Fun puzzle, and just four seconds off my best.

I have to disagree with Crystal on the movie Clue. We didn't like it at all. After watching that in the theater when it first came out, we wouldn't let our friend Mary Li pick movies any more.
Although newer Macs have removed the word Alt from the Option key, a lot of apps still call it Alt in their keyboard shortcut setups.

interesting word, HOLLA.  I always thought of it as a noun ("give me a holla") but TIL it can also be the actual expressed greeting. And while current use surely harkens to "holler," Dictionary.com (can I trust it?) says it dates back to the 1500s as a contraction of the French "ahoy la," apparently kin to the Spanish "hola." Strangely, I had never put holla and hola together before.

I love crossword puzzles.  Great debut, Mr. Hall.

Congratulations on your debut, Nate! Fun puzzle and a new speed record for a Tuesday for me, so I definitely was on your 53D-length! 

Looking forward to your next offering!

This was a fine Tuesday with some nice long themed answers.  I want to sing a song of praise for NEONATALNURSES.  My grandson spent his first two weeks in the  NICU, and the nurses there were angels, taking great care of him and keeping my daughter and son in law on an even keel during a time of great emotional stress.  I don‚Äôt know how they constantly deal with patients and their families at their most vulnerable and remain as empathetic and professional as they do.  

I also got a smile out the reference to CUTCO knives.  I learned everything I know about salesmanship from a friend who received training on how to PITCH CUTCO knives.  Two statements work in almost any situation: 1. That‚Äôs exactly why you need it; and 2. I used to think that.

This might be the most Naticky Tuesday I've ever seen.

I kept thinking 28A was LURE instead of AURA, and as I'm unfamiliar with the URAL mountain range or ALINE dresses it took a while to fix the issue.  Then with MGS having a crossing requiring you to know about British dogs and then a clue that feels like a stretch for the answer SLOPS, which then crossed a clue asking you to know where actors were born in OMAHA.  And I'm still not sure what HOLLA has to do with 'Heyo'.

Just way too many proper names and trivia made a frustrating solve.

I liked the theme clues at least.

Great debut Nate. Nice theme entries that had me guessing what the theme could be, and as a pediatrician I appreciate the NEONATALNURSE clue and the nurses themselves. That‚Äôs not a wet paint clue, we really do call them that‚Äîalthough to be honest they are often far too busy to do the rocking and we luckily have volunteers for that.

Interesting little story, when I was a resident I would do the rounds at night in the neonatal intensive care unit. Before bed I would often sing them songs  and every night would have a theme (yes Andrzej often show tunes‚Äîpoor babes). I also told them that if they slept and didn‚Äôt have any issues through the night they could come to me when they were 5 and I would buy them an ice cream. No one took me up on it.

Anyway, fun puzzle, fun clues. I especially enjoyed the call out to TCHALLA and Yogi BEAR who indeed must have been a cub sometime.

Well, this was a ROCKing good time.
Well-done theme, fresh fill, some twists and tweaks.

Thanks, Nate.

Fantastic debut, Nate. We are all Queen fans in my family, including my kids. We joke that we‚Äôve put them through the school of rock. ü§òüèº 
My middle child spent his first three weeks of life in the NICU, and he definitely got lots of rocking time when he wasn‚Äôt in his incubator. ü•∞ NEONATAL NURSES are all heroes in my book. As a native Californian, I have experienced more than my fair share of TECTONIC PLATE movement ü§£ And I have ridden a MECHANICAL BULL exactly one time and that was definitely my last! ü§† 
I mentioned my love of Psych yesterday. The 100th episode was 100 Clues and featured cast members from the movie CLUE as well as Curt Smith from Tears for Fears. One of the best episodes IMO. 

Thank you, Nate. YOU ROCKed us with this one ü§òüèºüé∏

Fun, quick puzzle! And a funny moment wondering if those dating show men could be lunks or punks lol. 

The mini today though, whew. I haven't ever had to do a lookup on a mini before but finally had to cave. Perfect combo of 4/5 cultural references outside of my lane plus a two line vague cross clue. Probably just me though.
14 seconds off my Tuesday best. My time in Africa has come to an end. En route to Paris, then back home. Glad I managed to find time to do the puzzle each day while away

Tired tonight,  so for some reason put in TEUTONIC PLATE.

Hmm: serving dish for sp√§tzle and bratwurst?

And: it will rock you because it‚Äôs the best sp√§tzle and bratwurst you ever had?

Nice and simple to solve.  Trying to come up with another way WEWILLROCKYOU, however, has me appreciating that it was likely much harder to construct.

My best thought: "Someone you don't want to offend in a back alley?  STREETFIGHTER."
But "rock you" to mean "beat you up" is probably too niche/generational.  I'll leave the constructing to the experts...

Also, I'm pleased to report that I have actually seen 36A.  Usually, if it's an 80s reference, I don't have a CLUE.

Fun puzzle, and a Tuesday PB for me!

P.S. BALI, JAVA, and BATIK in the same puzzle? Seems like someone has Indonesia on the brain!

Very fine puzzle.  Well done.  

Thank you for the nod to Minnesota.  It was well taken today.
Congratulations on your debut, Nate!  A thoroughly enjoyable puzzle. Loved the rock themed answers and the BEARCUB clue.  Thanks for being a mentor, Ian!
Lots of fun, and a Tuesday PB of 11 minutes for me. I particularly enjoyed all three of the rocking clues!

Delightful puzzle!
Think ‚ÄúKiss and Heart‚Äù is my new favorite clue
üíãü©∑
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2026/01/12/tuesday-january-13-2026/#ny

Geologists study granite-tary motion.

(It's gneiss work if you can get it.)
I really enjoyed this puzzle. Many of the clues had more than one potential answer and I had to backtrack quite a bit.
A very nice puzzle with a 'rocking' good theme.  I hope to see more puzzles from Nate Hall!  Thank you!

As I sit here at my desk, still 2 hours from dawn, watching it sleet outside my window, I‚Äôm humming my new favorite song, the earworm courtesy of the [‚ÄúHeyo!‚Äù] clue. Only the one I‚Äôm humming‚Äîyes, yes, Se√±or Gato, I know singing disturbs cats, but your lying on my keyboard (so much for having a LAPCAT) isn‚Äôt exactly conducive to my working, now is it. Anyhow, as I was saying, the song I‚Äôm humming has ‚Äúheyo‚Äù spelled a little differently: it goes, ‚ÄúHejo, guter alter Mond,‚Äù and it‚Äôs a snowshoeing song my nieces thrice removed infected me with over the Christmas break as we trekked through Bergen‚Äôs Seven Mountains (of which there aren‚Äôt seven; but I digress). It‚Äôs‚Ä¶ technically a kids‚Äô song? But I loved belting it out so much, even though I was admonished by my younger niece repeatedly‚Äîand with overt frustration‚Äîthat both my r‚Äôs and my vowels are hopelessly substandard. So, hejo to you all on this wintry Tuesday morning, and here goes: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=e691kkCRfK8

forgot this was today‚Äôs puzzle and not from the archive and was like wow there‚Äôs so few comments on this for such a simple clean solve‚Ä¶sigh i need to stop doing these in the middle of the night üò≠
BEAR CUB was really well clued. Very clever red herring type phrasing that makes you feel smart when it clicks. Also, any puzzle that mentions the film Clue is a winner in my book!

Fun and breezy, with a little kick! My solve time could have been a lot better. I‚Äôm getting worse because my Games app won‚Äôt work so I‚Äôm using the clunky browser version. The interface is more than a little awkward.
So badly don‚Äôt follow the Marvel universe I nearly misnamed the wonderful Ella Fitzgerald, a cultural travesty avoided. ‚ÄúYogi, once‚Äù has to be the clue of the month vote so far.
Welcome Nate, and thank you for a gorgeous puzzle.
To the constructor and editors: That was excellent restraint in clueing 12D.

Brilliant debut Nate!! After the horror that was last Tuesday, this was a delightful puzzle. Enjoyed solving this one, the Theme and the revealers along with the cluing was top notch!! Keep em' coming.

Funny how everyday the last several days in the puzzles, seeing ice is so jarring. 

This isn't a complaint and I get it. It's a common crossword ease. Still.

My husband has been a citizen of the United States for about 55 years.... Arguably, and I will fight to the death for this, he's the most amazing and wonderful human being ever! 

But lately, here, in a place we've called home for so very long, he has to carry his passport just to go to Walgreens... Or wherever. 

Oh yeah, the puzzle was great. Thumbs up!
No, I will not agree that Queen is the greatest rock band ever. Not even The Beatles or The Rolling Stones. For me, it will always be The Band. Puzzle was fun though.
Nice to see three Indonesia-related clues: 9-A, 58-A, 41-D. Fun puzzle!

What a sweet puzzle, love the theme. 
Yes, sadly 12D I fear will forever be tarnished by current events. I may be reading more into recent crosswords than is intended, but do I detect a little NYT resistance movement in the inclusion of certain clues? Today it‚Äôs 43D (what a missed opportunity). My addled brain can‚Äôt remember what else stood out, but I‚Äôm definitely picking up a vibe. Good work editors.

19A brought up a memory of the early days of my first born. All my offspring were born early and Small For Dates. (I deny it was because I could not be bothered cooking them the whole 9 months). This meant they spent a few days in NEONATAL. I went into the unit on day 3 post birth, said hello to the NURSE, who was ROCKing a baby, then walked off to his incubator. Finding it empty I turned in horror back to the nurse, imagining the worst. Yes, dear reader, it was my son in her arms that I had not recognised. Cue much teasing until he was eventually released to my, clearly incompetent, charge.  He‚Äôs now expecting his own firstborn any day now.

Despite the rocky theme I didn't experience any turbulence. A very smooth and enjoyable ride.

Congratulations, Nate, on an impressive debut.

Had the wrong Yogi at first and entered CATCHER. He's my all time favorite baseball player and I strove to emulate him during my all-too-brief baseball days. But like my brief career, I had to pivot to another favorite Yogi.

Excellent crossword!
It all fitted together so well. I think the yogi clue is going to be a favourite. I only fairly recently learnt that the bear's name was based on a real person. The NYT is so educational.

Voting is still ongoing for THE GRIDDIES! You have three days left to vote for your favorite crossword puzzles of 2025, The Griddies! You all have nominated about 100 puzzles, showing what a good year 2025 was (for xwords, anyway). Here's the schedule moving forward: 1/11 - 1/16: Voting on First Round; voting ends 11:59pm EST 1/18 - 1/25: Voting for Second (Final) Round 2/1: Announcement of winners & runners-up Here is the ballot: https://form.jotform.com/253465756808167 The ballot is easy to use. Vote for as many as five in each category; at the end, click "Submit" and you're all done, until the next round! Anyone can participate; the ballot has descriptions of the puzzles, but all the puzzles are easily accessed in archives: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/archive You'll see other announcements from Eric Hougland about this; if you have any questions, you can reply to this post or one of Eric's and someone will get back to you!
Last week Tuesday was Wednesday, and this week Monday was Tuesday and Tuesday is Monday.  PB for me today as well.

I‚Äôm not sure when the old one-two punch became a Yoga move, but those two clues were smarter than your average pair.


‚Ä¶and boo-boo inducing, reasoning-wise.

Side note on ASANA.  In a recent puzzle, YOGA was clued [Discipline for the flexible].  Well, yes, it is, so it passes as a clue.  But it is misleading, as it implies that yoga is only for bendy people.  In actuality, it is also for the non-bendy, medium-bendy, and everyone else.  It brings benefits to all.

Zoomed through it! Very close to the 'artificial' PB the Times gave me.
A fun puzzle; more like a Monday, but I'll take it!

33D. was a surprise for me. I have a few of that brand I got at an estate sale some time ago. One I use on a regular basis on apples, cantaloupe, and watermelon, Oh My!

I'll think of this puzzle every time I go to use one.
HOLLA? SRSLY? C'mon now...

I have to say that Tuesday puzzles have especially shined recently, with sparkling themes that made me go ‚ÄúOh!‚Äù rather than ‚ÄúOh.‚Äù  Like today's.

The best kind of riddles, IMO, are those you struggle mightily to crack, but remain impervious to your efforts.  Finally, you cave, then get the answer, and it turns out to be SO OBVIOUS, you wonder how in the world you missed it.

That‚Äôs the best way to be gotten.  And that‚Äôs what I got today after leaving the reveal blank and trying to guess what it was.  

Speaking of sparkling, three of those theme answers are NYT debuts, and the fourth  (MECHANICAL BULL) is a once-before.  Nate also beautified the grid, with NICHE, SCONCE, ADEPT, and BATIK.

SERENDIPITY WATCH.  Rare sighting of seven double-L‚Äôs, plus, a rare-in-crosswords five-letter palindrome (SOLOS).

Creating this theme out of that iconic rock song title ‚Äì well, that‚Äôs prime constructor mind, Nate.  Congratulations on your NYT debut, and thank you for this!

I loved this puzzle, so I feel a bit guilty about nitpicking, but I have to ask‚Äîis the inclusion of AD in both a clue (24A) and an answer (66A) not a crossword no-no? Normally wouldn‚Äôt stand out to me since it‚Äôs such a minuscule word, but considering that it has the same sense in both usages, I forwent entering ADS for 66A on my first pass because I thought it wasn‚Äôt allowed. Maybe that rule only applies to words that are three letters or longer (unpluralized)!

Like I said, though, delightful puzzle all around. My favorite answer was T‚ÄôCHALLA, especially because the late Chadwick Boseman has been on my mind lately.
A great puzzle, held myself back by confidently putting NEONATOLOGIST in. All the more satisfying to fix!

Fabulous Tues-debut!

Themers all felt fresh and,
*totally* unrelated.

Revealer was a...champion.

Are we, my friends?
This was a very Monday Tuesday but a fun solve nonetheless... and Roger Miller's England Swings is today's earworm.
Easy monday

Limp theme, questionable cluing, and a smattering of random trivia made this an overall unsatisfying solve. Looking forward to seeing this constructor grow. Glad others seemed to have a better time with it. Happy Tuesday.

My dog is a Zoomer. Every time he takes off on a tear around the house, all I can do is hold my breath and hope nothing breaks. 

I enjoyed this puzzle. Reasonably challenging, but gentle as a NEONATAL NURSE.

Had to guess at the HOLLA/TCHALLA intersection, but only H made sense to me. 

Realized today that TIMWALZ and JDVANCE both fit in seven boxes.

Just looked back at my completed grid and saw CUTCO, which appeared entirely from the crosses. Which is good, since seeing the answer I had no idea what a clue would be.

The two different appearances of "Yogi" was cute.

Congrats on the debut!

Well... not all that easy for me, but managed to work it out. Two of the theme answers and the reveal were all debut entries. And.. even the other theme answer had only ever appeared once before. That's unusual. 

Mostly just a lot of working the crosses and pondering until something dawned on me. Good puzzle. 

That's all.
I do not get how "PLATES" will "ROCK YOU".

Wonderfully surprising reveal!

But-and I'm sorry if this is too political-is no one enforcing child labor laws in this country? Neonatal nurses?! smh

Really enjoyed this one, and loving it even more after learning that it‚Äôs a debut! I feel like the clues and answers were diverse enough to appeal to solvers from all generations. Love the clever theme, especially TECTONIC PLATES. Growing up in California in the 1970s, we learned all about them, along with our duck-and-cover drills, so the term‚Äôs been in my memory about as long as the lyrics to WE WILL ROCK YOU.

For the last few weeks (ever since you updated to a new version of your app) I have had trouble accessing the NYT puzzle page. Initially the update gave you the option of ‚Äúnot now ‚Äú but then that stopped for some reason. I can‚Äôt update on my iPad unless I have the most recent iOS update and I can‚Äôt get the most recent version because my old iPad doesn‚Äôt have the storage space. I really don‚Äôt want to go out and buy a new iPad for $1000+ just to do the daily crossword which is the only NYT game I do on the app. Could you please give us old troglodytes the ‚Äúnot now ‚Äú option back on you update notice
Thank you

This was a fun puzzle. I enjoyed the theme and had a laugh when I saw the revealer. WE WILL ROCK YOU was my high school basketball team‚Äôs warm up song. I loved the answer for Yogi, once. Thanks, Nate! Y‚Äôall have a peaceful Tuesday! It‚Äôs a beautiful, sunny day in the NC mountains.üåû

"Heyo"??  HOLLA??  

Hmm... so a MECHANICAL BULL "ROCKs" riders?  Then I suppose a 7.2 earthquake is just a jiggle.  
The biggest quake we experienced whilst dwelling in Northern California was a 6.3.  Did it "ROCK us?"  Um, no.  More like a very firm JOUNCE--an up-and-down shaking that made it hard to get down the hallway and snatch up the sleeping darlings on the way to the front door.  Talk about your "rude awakenings."  Not my most popular move.  

Oh.  The puzzle:
I got NEONATALOGIST right off the bat!  Only, of course, that wasn't entirely correct.  The hard-working, busy-every-moment NURSEs at the NICU seldom if ever sat down to ROCK, but they were geniuses at picking up a baby with tubes, bandages, IVs, stitches, oxygen, etc., and putting that baby right into your empty arms.  It was only 45 years ago, so--still fresh in my mind.

Overall pretty easy and fun puzzle, loved the Queen reference, but needed a couple letters before I knew the actual song. 

Finishing the puzzle was a bit tricky and required some guessing for me (BATIK?? CLODS? Also MGS/SLOPS ?) Slops for spills is a bit strange to me‚Ä¶ and never heard of something slopping over.  otherwise pretty fun and approachable puzzle!
This is my all time personal best time! By one second haha but I'll take it! A fun puzzle

Congrats Nate! A fun Tuesday solve. Not sure why but I love the clue at 49 across - maybe because I get hung up on this particular kind of clue fairly frequently and a singer‚Äôs pitch could be construed as a tool to sell music? It produced that giggle/groan that I love about doing these crosswords! (Autotune would‚Äôve been a great clue in this puzzle ‚Äî but I bet Queen never used it!)

Smooth Tuesday for me, just off a PB. 
‚ÄòYogi, once‚Äô is a delightful clue.  

Speaking of which I have to admit I have not seen ‚ÄòClue.‚Äô Time to fix that!

Nice column also! Very fun to have guest columnists - although Deb will always be missed.
I enjoyed today
Raise your hand if you, put FLOOR, for the caution wet clue.
That's plenty of Indonesian references right there üòÇ

Also led wtih NEONAToLogiSt which caused no end of trouble to start with.  Nice debut, [Concern for a singer or a salesman] for PITCH the favorite but [Yogi, once] a close runner up. 

Well done and thanks.
The Inca were not known for pyramids. That would be the Mexica (Aztecs) or the Maya.
Deep Fake AI videos ‚Äî MECHANICALBULL

I have a strategy question, and am seeking advice.

Here's what led me to ask this of fellow solvers: I always start by cycling through the across clues, typing in my best guesses, then doing the same for the downs (which often show that my across guesses were wrong).  Today I hand many more squares filled after my across pass than usual, but many turned out to be incorrect.  So my question is, early on, do you think it better to enter a word when unsure, or to leave it blank until the fill provides some letter clues?  Sometimes my wrong answers lead me astray, my brain can't handle the distraction of errant squares.  Maybe if I'd left them blank, I'd have an easier time of it?  Or is typing in an answer that has a high possibility of being incorrect the stronger approach?

I don't know which approach is best for me and am curious as to how other solvers do their work.
I loved this Tuesday puzzle with just enough pushback, Nate Hall! Also thanks to Crystal Arroyo for a great column and wow what a dedicated streak!
I simply cannot believe that I didn't know the birth place of a Marvel comics character. And I will now forget it --- as quickly as possible,
Finished 6 seconds off my Tuesday best, pretty fun one

I read through 100 comments and never saw anyone address the size. It's 14x16. I thought all (or 99.9%) NYT crosswords were 15x15. Curious if it's meaningful to the theme, or just something they're now willing to do.
My college roommate got a summer job selling CUTCO knives door-to-door. He quit after a week - nobody wants those.

Recently, it seems like the Tuesday crossword is the one I am most likely to spend more time than average to solve.  It is not a bad thing for an early-in-the-week puzzle to put up a little bit of a fight.
Classic British cars = MGB

When I saw Yogi once, my first thought was catcher. The across answers nixed that right away and led me to bear cub.
I think wet paint is more prevalent than wet floor, although I see both frequently.
I had no idea about the Marvel references, but the fill answered them.
In response to Don H, when I see an answer has more than one possible answer, I see if there is an unusual letter in the crossings that will guide me.

Today‚Äôs poem. a/=across clues‚Ä¶ d/=down clues‚Ä¶. a/=answers

a/ caution climbs 
an antlered path 
tending the pendulum‚Äôs endings
d/ i marvel most 
in mountain pose
that little life like light might ride
a/ a snail wave
Pitch perfect for a Tuesday. The theme wasn't overbearing, the clues were clear, there were no tiresome "tricks," and it was just me against the clock. A new personal best time for Tuesdays.

A fun puzzle, with interesting clues. When the theme clicked I got such a jolt of joy - I was grinning ear to ear and had to share the theme with everyone in the room. We can all use a little joy.

Let me join the chorus of those who had Wet Floor before Wet Paint. Glad I‚Äôm not alone.

Clue was one of my old roommates‚Äô comfort movie, and so I‚Äôve seen it many many times. I think the third, long ending is my favorite, but I love the commonalities between them - the monkey brain soup, ‚ÄúCommunism was a red herring?‚Äù etc. Definitely worth a watch or two to those who haven‚Äôt yet had the pleasure!
This was a lot of fun. Maybe a bit easy for Tuesday but the reveal at the end was fantastic. Thank you!

Not a week goes by that I don‚Äôt quote Tim in Clue, it was the film that I watched most growing up and my friends and I can recite it from start to finish. Tim Curry, especially his performance in Clue, was a major influence on me in my formative years and inspired me to act in theater productions in my youth.  There is no one like him and never will be. His presence, his face, his voice are one of a kind, a true original. I received his new autobiography ‚ÄúVagabond‚Äù as a Christmas gift this year and am enjoying reading it by the fire in the evenings immensely. 

But with that said, the award for most-quoted line in Clue still goes to the great Madeline Kahn, another true original:

‚Äúflames..on the side of my face‚Ä¶heaving, breathless, heaving breaths, heaving..‚Äù
Congratulations on your debut Mr. Hall, a fun one to solve.  I must admit I never heard of HOLLA before.  Is it more common in one area of the country than in others?
Loved this puzzle! The reveal made me lol.
Soda(s) or Cola(s); you forgot Coke(s).
Fun super quick grid. And TIL it's LEDE, not LEAD.
lovely puzzle :) 4d. really messed me up for a bit i was convinced it was birth place not birth name after 3d. haha

Regarding the crossword for Wednesday, 1/14/2026, there isn‚Äôt an info page for the puzzle. No page, therefore no comments! I love looking at the puzzle info page, especially after completing the crossword without using any hints! Please keep running the column for us! Please!
@Crystal Arroyo This answer might not be valid, but I like all three endings edited together in the film. That aside, the best one is C and I think most would agree

@Crystal Arroyo I was so excited to see CLUE as an answer. 

I agree that the third ending is the best. So many good quotes as well! ‚ÄòFlames, flames, on the side of my face‚Ä¶‚Äô

@Charles Nelson Reilly

It is 100% valid to love all three edited together. It is the multiple endings that make this movie stand out so much. Part of my love of the last one is the buildup from the previous two.

@Crystal Arroyo

My favourite of the three endings would have to be :
"How It Could Have Happened".
In which Miss Scarlet is revealed as the mastermind.

Mainly due to her debate with Wadsworth over how many bullets remain in the revolver.

Was it One + Two + Two + One, or One + Two + One + One?

@Crystal Arroyo You may enjoy his new book, Vagabond. It‚Äôs not a kiss-and-tell tawdry thing, but a lively journey through the events that led him to playing villains with such nuance and personality.

@Crystal Arroyo they did a theatrical rerelease last year on the occasion of the 40th anniversary and apparently they screened it as they originally had, with only one ending per screening and changing up the ending each night.

@Dan

It‚Äôs a getaway mostly for foreigners; that is to say, a well-known vacation spot. 

Many tropical islands are. 

As to your second bit, really?  You do realize that the neonatal part refers to the patient, not the nurse???  (Of course you do, so was that supposed to be a joke?). 

As to your final nit, the answer is simple. Mild misdirection.

@Steve L

I'm not quite sure Dan was being serious, Steve.
But of course, these are not "nits" in the sense of claims that the crossword violated some rule governing crossword construction. No, they are just my personal reaction to those clues.
@Dan You'd have a point if the clue read "Grocery shops without a partner" as in "I just free solo'd Whole Foods", but it is a term used specifically in climbing.

Aaron ‚Äî I am well aware of the term "free solo".

But did you notice that the word "free" was not involved in any way?

@Dan

You're going to be lots of fun, aren't you?
@Dan as it turns out, "solo" is also a climbing term.

@Steve L
Tch! In order to create a fully rounded and mature character like Yogi Bear, a back story is a necessity. And every back story starts the same way: You were born...

@SBK

Adam and Eve of the garden of Eden would like a word with you! (Not like Adam's a fully rounded and mature character though, is he)
